sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a dissolution reaction
message_1: Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the dissolution of 10 g of NaOH in 100 mL of water at 25°C if the molar enthalpy of dissolution is -44.5 kJ/mol.
message_2:
First, we need to determine the number of moles of NaOH in 10 g. The molar mass of NaOH is:

NaOH = 22.99 g/mol (Na) + 15.999 g/mol (O) + 1.007 g/mol (H) = 39.996 g/mol

Now, we can calculate the number of moles of NaOH:

moles of NaOH = mass / molar mass
moles of NaOH = 10 g / 39.996 g/mol = 0.2501 mol

Next, we can calculate the standard enthalpy change for the dissolution of 0.2501 mol of NaOH using the given molar enthalpy of dissolution:

ΔH = moles × molar enthalpy of dissolution
ΔH = 0.2501 mol × (-44.5 kJ/mol) = -11.129 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the dissolution of 10 g of NaOH in 100 mL of water at 25°C is -11.129 kJ.
